kummins.misc

Class Timer

  • java.lang.Object
    • kummins.misc.Timer

  • public class Timer
extends java.lang.Object
    Real-time stopwatch based on system time. The primary purpose of this tool is for timing code blocks and optionally monitoring the number of calculations made and attempts at a solution.

    While it is conceptually easy to consider the timer as being active or not, the class in fact remains dormant when not specifically being called, due to the way in which it utilises the host system's clock by comparing start and end times. It's unit is milliseconds, although it's accuracy is determined by the quality of the host system clock.

    Example use:
    Timer t = new Timer(false);
    System.out.println(t.start());
    while (!solved) {
       x = 2*y-z;
       t.calculation();
       y = z+a;
       t.calculation();
       if (isCorrect()) {
         solved = true;
       }
       t.attempt();
    }
    System.out.println(t.stop());

    Here, an object of type Timer is instantiated and used to measure the elapsed time of an operation, along with the number of attempts and calculations before it was considered complete. The elapsed time and number of calculations and attempts are printed to standard output. See the method documentation for further information.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Chris Cummins

      Constructor and Description

      Constructs an object of type timer and starts it immediately.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      Registers another attempt.

      Starts the timer.
      java.lang.String stop()
      Stops the timer and returns the time elapsed.
      long time()
      Returns the currently elapsed time if active, or the last recorded time if stopped.
      java.lang.String toString()
      Produces a string report of the status of the timer, along with values for elapsed or total time.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Timer

        public Timer(boolean active)
        Constructs an object of type timer and specifies whether it is active. If false it will remain dormant. Useful for delayed starts or printing the start command to standard output.
        Parameters:
        active - Boolean value to determine whether it is active or not.

      • Timer

        public Timer()
        Constructs an object of type timer and starts it immediately. Equivalent to new Timer(true)

                      throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Stops the timer and returns the time elapsed.
        Returns:
